text:
Stomach clenching and bile rising high in his throat, Izuku keeps his eyes on the screen even as he fidgets.  His hands twist themselves together and apart over and over again, nails digging into scar tissue to keep himself from picking at his nail beds until they bleed.

He used to do that constantly growing up.  His fingertips had been one massive, throbbing ache for years on end, raw and hurting from ragged, bitten down nails and ruthlessly peeled back cuticles.  The pain had been grounding though, had helped to keep him aware and together through everything.

That had been one of the things most people in school had known about him when he was younger. He was quirkless first before anything else, he was a creepy mumbler who always scribbled in his notebooks second, and he was the gross kid whose fingers were almost always either actively bleeding or wrapped up in bandages.

It’s a habit he’d only managed to break the year before when having open wounds on his hands would have been equal to basically begging for an infection since he’d spent most of his free time elbow deep in trash at Dagobah Beach.

It’s a habit he’s honestly considering taking back up right now despite how much he knows any new kind of damage to his hands and arms, no matter how superficial, would be an overall bad idea.

It’s hard to bring himself to really care at the moment though because Izuku knows that he’s going to fail his final exam.

Because, once again, he’s been paired with Kacchan.  Only this time, instead of fighting one another, they’re supposed to be working as a team against a larger threat.

And the larger threat they’re going up against is going to be All Might.

There is, Izuku knows with a ragged sort of certainty, no way they’ll be passing this exercise.

And, if the sympathetic glances from Iida and Uraraka as well as the displeased light in Todoroki’s expression is anything to go by, then he’s not the only one who’s already realized that.

~~~

Izuku had learned a long time ago not to ask his teachers for anything.

Tamakawa-sensei had taught him that in elementary school with long hours spent standing in the hall outside of the classroom.  With days where he’d been forced to balance dictionaries on his hands or to hold up a pail of water no matter how much his arms ached from the stress.

All because he’d asked a question that Tamakawa-sensei had considered unnecessary.  And any and every question Izuku had ever asked had always been deemed unnecessary.

Izuku had learned real fast how to handle his own issues in class, how to research and teach himself anything he didn’t understand.

Every teacher he’s had since then has only ever reinforced that lesson with sneers or extra cleaning duties that quickly became him taking over all cleaning duties, or whatever other punishment they could think of to ‘teach him the realities of life for someone like him'.

Aizawa-sensei, for all of his occasional harshness, has been the fairest teacher Izuku’s ever had.  Being in the man’s homeroom has been a pleasant sort of change for Izuku for the most part, as has most of his classes with the heroes teaching at UA if he’s being honest.

But that doesn’t mean Izuku trusts the man, that doesn’t mean he really trusts any of them except for All Might.

He knows they would protect him from villains, just like they’d protect the rest of his classmates.  Aizawa and Thirteen both had almost died for his class at the USJ, Aizawa-sensei especially given the damage that had been dealt to him from both Shigaraki and the Nomu.

Izuku has no doubts that any of the other teachers would have done the same in their positions.

The teachers at UA are heroes.  It’s who and what they are.  So of course they’d stand between villains and their students, heroes in training or not.

Of course they would.  Of course Izuku trusts them with that.

But on a personal level?  When things like class work and homework assignments and punishments are concerned?

Izuku knows better than to expect much in any of those departments, knows better than to expect much of anything if he’s being honest.

But, in this moment and against all of these well known and long learned odds, Izuku’s also desperate.

He doesn’t want to fail.  Not again, not here, not against All Might who is counting on him for so much and has already given him more than anyone else in his entire life.

So, despite the way everything inside of him rebels at the very idea, despite the way he’s already sure this won’t work, Izuku still has to try.

“Sensei,” Izuku murmurs quietly as he slides up to Aizawa’s side, arms crossed over his chest and hands twisting in the fabric of his costume to try and still the urge to bite.

“Problem Child,” Aizawa stares down at him, one brow arched in question but face otherwise blank.

“I-I know it’s really late and really selfish and that there’s a point to these m-matchups and for you putting me and ...” Izuku swallows roughly, words coming out in a mix of stuttering and half finished sentences as he tries not to shake, “I know ... t-teamwork is important ... b-b-but can you, can we, c-could …”

Izuku trails off, his mouth and throat working but his voice gets trapped somewhere he can’t quite reach it.

“Kid,” Aizawa sighs just a bit, obviously exasperated and Izuku has to bite back his instinctive flinch, “what’s this about?”

Izuku pauses, swallows again, and gathers as much determination and grit as he can get his mental hands on.

“Can you please give Kacchan a different partner?”  Izuku finally manages to get the question out.  “H-We can’t work together.  Not for this exam.”

There’s a long moment of silence and when Izuku finally manages to look up again he can’t help but blanch just a bit at the disappointment that’s so blatantly plain in Aizawa-sensei’s expression then.

“I’ve got a half mind to fail you right here,” Aizawa tells him, voice that dangerous sort of soft it gets when someone makes a mistake he absolutely can’t abide by.

Izuku hates being on the receiving end of it.

“You said you know teamwork is important, right Midoriya?” Aizawa keeps going, something almost frustrated lurking in the corners of his mouth.  “You’re going to have to work with all kinds of heroes if you make it pro, no matter what your personal relationship is with them.  So this rivalry between you and Bakugou?  You need to learn to work with or around it because if you don’t and you fail this exam … I might have to reevaluate your potential.  And it might not be just the summer camp you end up missing.”

Izuku doesn’t say anything else.

Instead he just turns his face to the side as he folds down in on himself a bit more, bobs his head in a shallow nodding bow, and slinks away back towards where Todoroki has been watching him.

His friend doesn’t say anything to him, just brushes their shoulders together in a move so subtle Izuku almost doesn’t feel it given how deep into his own head he’s managed to sink.

He should have kept his mouth shut.

Asking a teacher for help had, once again, done nothing but make things worse.

Just like it always has for him. 

~~~

Izuku chases after Kacchan, stays right on his heels as they both sprint through the gate and into the mock city.

“K-Kacchan,” Izuku calls out to his teammate. “W-We need to make a plan or something.  It’s All Might so maybe we should just run ‘cause th-there’s no way we can fight him.  It’s All Might.”

The hit to the face isn’t a surprise really.

A part of Izuku was even expecting it.

Was waiting to feel that familiar burning crackle against his skin, the long familiar scent of burnt caramel flooding his senses as pain ripples out across his face like spider web fractures in a foundation.

What is a surprise is the way that something in his mind just …

Shatters.

Izuku greys out around the edges.

Something inside of him takes a step back and to the left until he’s almost standing outside of his own body and watching the world pass by around him.

It’s a feeling Izuku hasn’t had in a long time now.

But it’s still one he knows.

~~~

Izuku doesn’t really remember the rest of the exam.

Is only aware of it in a vague sort of way as his body moves and fights and runs and hurts all without his real consent or input.

Izuku gets up.

He runs.

There’s wind and fire, there’s fists and feet and screaming.

The pop crackle pop of explosions.

He gets back up, pushes himself up and away from metal and concrete and shattered glass.

He keeps running.

That’s something he’s always known how to do.

~~~

Pop.

Coward. Coward. 

Crackle.

Useless fucking coward.  All you ever do is run. 

Pop.

Stand still and take it.

~~~

They win.

Somehow, despite everything and against all odds, they win.

They win but Kacchan is still so angry.

Is still so pissed and vicious about something Izuku’s done or not done or, maybe, just at Izuku existing in his general vicinity.

Izuku isn’t really sure which it is.

All of the above more than likely.

Izuku just lets him scream, lets him threaten and curse at him, lets him pop off his quirk in his face like he’s been doing since they were four and Izuku stopped being a real person in Kacchan’s eyes.

Izuku just stands there and takes it even after they’re back in the viewing room with the others and Kacchan still hasn’t calmed all the way down.

Aizawa gives him a shallow nod, All Might says something that, for once, Izuku doesn’t actually pay attention to.

Uraraka and Iida smile and talk.

Todoroki stands at his side, a silent but steady presence.

Izuku just …

Drifts.

~~~

Later, once they’ve all filed back onto the bus and ridden back to the main campus, Izuku still finds himself covered in that familiar grey haze.

Still finds himself standing just beside his own body and watching everything pass him by.

In the end Izuku sits there on the bus, cheek, back, head, and heart all aching, for the longest time.

He stays there long after everyone else has already cleared out except for him and Todoroki who’d waved Iida and Uraraka away and then stayed sitting silently in the seat beside him.

Izuku sits and exists and doesn’t do much else but those two things.

Todoroki drifts out of the bus somewhere around the two hour mark with one last, lingering look at Izuku.

But still, Izuku just stays.

Sunset comes, the bus is awash in fiery reds and oranges that make Izuku uncomfortable for some reason he can’t exactly place.

Body aching in a way he almost registers, head stuffed full of cotton and vision grey around the edges, Izuku finally gets up.

He leaves.

Not all of him walks away.

~~~

Izuku’s been a patchwork person for as long as he can remember.

Fractures and scars sewed together with tears and apologies, held together by a thin thread of hope and built on a shaky base of please I just want to be a hero I just want to help let me help please.

But ...

All threads fray eventually.

All bases under heavy stress break down.

Fatigue fractures spreading outwards like spider webs.

~~~

Recovery Girl scolds him again, tells him she’s only going to heal him up after his normal ridiculous recklessness because the burn and the fractures in his cheek and jaw would make it difficult for him to eat.  Because the dislocated shoulder can’t be left alone.

The bruises will have to heal naturally because she swears, yet again, that she won’t keep doing this, won’t enable him and his reckless, self destructive tendencies.

Izuku just nods, shrugs, and walks away.

School nurses have never liked Izuku much, have always gotten exasperated with his injuries and tired of seeing him after a few weeks into each new school year.  To her credit Recovery Girl has lasted longer than most.

It doesn’t matter either way.

Izuku got used to patching himself up a long time ago.  The few months he’s had in UA haven’t erased all of his hardwon and long perfected first aid skills.

He can save Recovery Girl’s remaining scraps of goodwill for anything too extensive to handle on his own.

Either way he’ll get by.

Like he always has.

~~~

Life becomes a collection of actions for Izuku in the days after the exam.  Becomes a series of tasks instead of experiences.

It goes from the routine he’d slowly, cautiously, hopefully, settled into back to the almost rhythmic sort of flow that used to be all that got him through his day to day life growing up.

It becomes:

Wake up. Train. Eat. Go to class. Smile. Nod. Train. Hurt. Sit. Stand. Smile. Train. Sleep. Wake up gasping alone in his room, chest heaving and throat sore from nightmares memories he can’t won’t remember. 

Repeat. Repeat. Repeat.

Izuku exists.

He doesn't do much else.

~~~

Sometimes, in his clearer, more present moments, Izuku thinks about his last year of elementary school.

Or, to be more accurate, he thinks about the fact that he doesn't really remember most of it.

He’s got the scars to prove that it had happened but ...

He'd existed then too, instead of living.

Izuku had hoped, had dreamed, that UA would be different.  That this school full of heroes and hero hopefuls and the best and brightest Japan had to offer would be better.

And for a while it had been.

And in some ways it still is.

But …

Izuku should have known better than to get his hopes up too high.

Good things rarely last.

And some things never change.

~~~

A thought that Izuku would have never dreamed he’d have begins to take shape in the back of his mind.

And, despite the way it feels almost like blasphemy, Izuku can’t shake it completely off.

~~~

Todoroki stops him one day in the locker room after training, keeps him behind as the others get dressed and head off towards the dorms and dinner.

“I don’t know how to help you,” Todoroki’s voice is calm and even but Izuku sees what looks a lot like worry in his mismatched eyes.  “Not like how you helped me.”

“I’m fine,” Izuku tells him absently, the same reassurance he’s been saying since he was four, five, eight, thirteen years old.

The same thing he’s always told his mom, the same thing he’d told Uraraka and Iida only the day before.

“You’re not,” Todoroki disagrees.  “The others might not see it but I can.  That look in your eyes …”

There’s an understanding in Todoroki’s voice, in the line of his shoulders, a knowing in the set of his mouth.

“The world’s really … grey, isn’t it Todoroki-kun?” Izuku asks almost absently as he reaches down to pick up his uniform shirt.

A cool hand stops him as fingertips trace over the collection of starbursts that litter the slope of his shoulder, spilling down and over his collarbone.

“Mine used to be,” Todoroki murmurs after a long, quiet moment.

“How’d you fix it?” Izuku asks the question softly, aware but not, mind still half way floating somewhere static and dull.

“I didn’t,” Todoroki tells him just as softly.

~~~

Izuku’s been running for so long now.

He doesn’t want to run anymore.

Doesn’t want to leave some of the things he’s finally found behind.

And yet ...

~~~

No one’s expecting the way Todoroki lashes out that evening.

The class is gathered in the dorm’s common room, dinner cooking in the kitchen and laughter heavy in the air.

Izuku sits curled up in the corner where Todoroki had put him earlier, notebook in hand and eyes trained out the window, with Todoroki himself a warm line of solidarity at his side.  Iida and Uraraka are settled on the love seat close to them, Tsuyu at Uraraka’s feet while she braids her hair and Iida watches with his special brand of intensity.

Everything is quiet and calm for the most part. But then Kaminari’s bray of laughter rings out across the room and a familiar pop crackle pop cuts through the air.

Izuku flinches.

Todoroki’s moving in the next moment.

He flows up and off of the couch from beside Izuku and there’s barely enough time to blink before spikes of ice are surging across the common room.

The attack sends Kacchan tumbling backwards from where he’d been hovering over Kaminari with a shout.  He hits the ground and rolls back up and onto his feet with a snarl even as he surges forwards to attack.

Todoroki, unphased, meets him halfway.

And this time, unlike at the Sports Festival, he does it with both his ice and his fire in hand.

The window behind Kacchan shatters and Izuku can only watch as he goes flying.

Someone screams.

Outside the dorm Kacchan roars.

~~~

Aizawa-sensei comes moments later, hair raised, eyes burning, and utterly furious.

Kacchan has to be full body restrained.

Todoroki just stands there passively with a loop of Aizawa’s capture scarf settled firmly around his waist.

Everyone else is confused and upset and a few even sound scared.

Izuku just looks back at Todoroki who’s been staring at him the entire time with something that feels almost like awe brewing to life inside of him, filtering in through the static and the haze he’s been living in.

Right before he’s dragged out of the dorm by Aizawa, Izuku’s sure he sees Todoroki smile.

~~~

Todoroki gets an entire week of house arrest, a month of detention, and an official warning.  He’ll also be stuck with the remedial classes during the training camp.

Whenever anyone, even the teachers, asks him why he just shrugs and turns away.

Izuku seems to be the only one who notices the way Todoroki always turns to look at him.

It makes him feel just a bit more awake and aware.

Makes him feel just a bit more real.

~~~

Sometimes, when the dorm is quiet and dark and his body feels real again for at least a little while, Izuku heads outside.

He'll slip out of his dorm window, feet bare so he can feel the coolness of night dew on the grass, and he'll just walk the small courtyard garden behind the dorm.

Back and forth, around and around, through the flowers and the small class vegetable plot Iida and Yaomomo had gotten permission for them to make.

Izuku waits, sort of absently and without really caring, to get in trouble for his night time activities, but no one ever calls him on it. He never gets reprimanded for breaking curfew or anything of the like.

No one says anything.

So either Nezu, who Izuku is sure probably knows, is content to leave him be or he’s been wrong about the level of surveillance the dorms are actually under all of the time and no one actually knows about his walks.

Both options are worthy of deeper thought but, either way, Izuku doesn't stop sneaking out.

Sometimes Todoroki even comes out onto his balcony despite how late it is.  Even when he’s on house arrest he’ll still come out to sit on the railing of his balcony like a silent sort of reassurance.

Sometimes Izuku will hop up to sit on the railing beside him, their shoulders pressed together and hands just brushing.

~~~

“If I didn’t go to UA anymore,” Izuku asks one night when the stars and his mind are both clear and bright and everyone but the two of them have all long since gone to sleep, “if I went to a different school, would you still be my friend?”

“I’d probably just transfer with you,” Todoroki tells him simply with a small, unconcerned shrug.

Izuku goes still.

“What?” Izuku whispers the question out through a throat gone tight with emotion.

“Shiketsu is a good school," Todoroki offers blandly.  "It's prestigious in its own right, and they’d take you in on scholarship after your showing in the Sports Festival if All Might doesn’t want to pay for your transfer."

Izuku stares up at him, eyes wide and heart pounding.

“We’re going to be heroes no matter what, Izuku,” Todoroki tells him like it’s obvious, like it’s a universal law, like the sound of his first name isn’t enough to make something inside of Izuku shake.  “UA isn’t the only place to do that and if you change schools then I’d rather be there with you than here without you.  Besides, even if Endeavor won’t pay for tuition if I transfer then I’ll apply for their scholarship too.  They’d probably jump at the chance to steal the son of the Number 2 hero from UA.”

Izuku absorbs that, swallows as best he can through the tightness in his throat.  The sigh he gives out is shaky at best.

“Yeah,” Izuku murmurs, just a bit dazed as tears gather at the corners of his eyes.  “I-I’d rather be with you too, S-Shouto.”

His hand shakes as he slides it across the railing and tentatively touches his fingertips to the back of Shouto’s.

Shouto just shifts his hand until their fingers are tangled together.

His warmth feels soothing against Izuku's scars.

And, for the first time in what feels like forever, Izuku breathes.

Izuku resettles into his body in bits and pieces.

‘Greying out’ as Izuku has always called this thing that happens to him, because some part of him shies away from the proper name for what happens to him and from what it implies about him and his life, has always been equal parts exhausting and dream-like.

It’s a strange state of being, living in half measures.  It’s draining, that long familiar feeling of being half aware and half drifting somewhere just left of where he knows he should be.

Of being breathless and breathing, sleeping and awake, of being greyed out everywhere and yet only around select edges all at the same time.

Regaining his color, resettling into his body, has always hurt, has always left Izuku feeling raw and wounded and ready to shake apart in the aftermath.

But this time …

This time things aren’t miraculously perfect but they are ... different.

This time instead of snapping harshly, painfully, back into place as he always has in the past, Izuku resettles slowly.

Bit by bit.

And, tucked away in that carefully shielded part of himself that’s always moving, always thinking and calculating and analyzing, Izuku knows that it’s because Shouto helps.

Having Shouto around, having him standing at his side or hovering just at his shoulder as he always seems to be these days, helps a lot more than Izuku had ever thought possible.

Helps more than anything or anyone Izuku’s ever had or known or thought of before.

When they sit together at lunch Shouto presses their knees together beneath the table and suddenly Izuku can taste what he’s eating again.  Food becomes food again instead of tasteless mush he’s obligated to consume to keep his body moving.

When they’re assigned paired classwork or during training blocks Shouto partners up with him at every given opportunity.  He moves so fast to claim the spot beside Izuku and then deadeye stares at anyone who gets too close.  Eventually the rest of the class stops asking altogether, seeming to accept that Izuku’s been declared off limits.

Either way Shouto never falters and Izuku never protests. Instead Shouto just pulls him to the side and Izuku goes willingly, content to be led by someone he knows won’t hurt him.  Shouto presses the both of them into the corner of the classroom or whatever training yard or gym they’re currently using, tucks the both of them as far from the others as possible.

Instead of feeling crowded or isolated Izuku finds that he can actually concentrate, can actually remember and experience things when it’s Shouto working at his side, Shouto standing between him and everyone else.

Shouto, quiet and calm but always there, gives Izuku room to breathe.

For the first time in his life Izuku has someone he doesn’t have to emotionally or physically hide from, has someone he doesn’t have to pretend for.

For the first time since he stopped being a person and started being a thing to the world at large, Izuku has someone beside him who allows him to simply … be.

Somehow that acceptance makes everything so much smoother.

Izuku knows it might just be proof that he’s weak, the need to have Shouto with him in order to be again, knows he should be trying to do all of this on his own, but …

All he really feels is protected.

Izuku’s never really been protected before, not like this, not from anything that wasn’t certain death.

And even then it wasn’t like this.

Nothing in Izuku’s life has ever felt like this.

Shouto is unlike anyone Izuku’s ever had in his life before.

~~~

But, just as Izuku learned when he was four, five, nine, fourteen years old and standing on the edge of a building, good things never last.

And, despite all his years of experience and no matter how much he might wish otherwise, Izuku can only run so fast.

Eventually the things that are chasing him have a tendency to catch up.

~~~

Hero schools don’t operate on the standard school schedule so even though they’ve had their final exams already, training and certain classes don’t actually stop.

Instead things shift a bit more towards the physical end of the spectrum with book classes being phased out until the next semester officially begins.  More group and specialized training slots into their places as the time until the training camp slowly clicks down.

Izuku knows what’s going to happen long before it does.

It’s easy to calculate the odds, to watch as the rest of the class is paired off and his options whittle down bit by bit.

So, by the time it happens, Izuku’s not even close to surprised.

“Final match up for the day will be young Midoriya and young Bakugou,” All Might announces cheerfully, smile bright and hands resting on his hips.

This time Izuku doesn’t even bother to glance at Aizawa who’s leaning against the wall overseeing things.  He doesn’t bother to look at any of his other classmates either.

Instead he just stares up at Shouto with something thin and aching stirring to life inside of his chest.

He’s been getting better, been settling, bit by bit every single day, but now …

Now he’s right back where he started, right back where he always seems to end up no matter the circumstances.

Facing off against Kacchan.

Because it seems as if that’s exactly where everything and everyone in his life but Shouto wants Izuku to be.

And Izuku already knows that nothing he says to any of the teachers will be enough to get him out of it.

“I can stop it,” Shouto offers, his hand wrapping around Izuku’s, seemingly uncaring that anyone could see the way their fingers tangled together if they bothered to look.  “Say the word and I’ll break him.”

It’s the kind of offer, the kind of fierce protection and unwavering support, that no one else has ever really extended to Izuku.

Shouto is ready and willing to interfere with the class, to get in trouble yet again with even harsher consequences.  Is ready to fight all to make sure that Izuku can walk away from this moment unscathed and avoid yet another brawl with Kacchan.

“No,” Izuku says softly, fingers squeezing around Shouto’s as he does his best to breathe. “It’s okay.”

This isn’t an exam where Izuku’s future depends on him somehow working with Kacchan as a team.  This is just training.  It’s just another class, just another fight, another battle, another familiar bit of pain and fear and exhaustion waiting to happen.

Izuku’s been doing this in one form or another for years.

He can handle it.

But the fact that Shouto offered? Was willing to put himself in the line of fire from multiple directions all for Izuku?

It means more to Izuku than he can say.

~~~

Later, once it’s done and training is over and everyone else has walked off laughing and groaning and happy with only a few scrapes and light bruises to show for the day, Shouto sits with Izuku inside the now quiet locker room.

Izuku’s body aches and exhaustion tugs at the edges of his senses, but he’s present.

Somehow, someway, he’s still aware.

But, given the fact that Shouto hasn’t left his side unless absolutely necessary, maybe it’s not that much of a surprise.

“You should see Recovery Girl,” Shouto murmurs from beside him, voice a deliberate sort of soft and even.

Izuku doesn’t have to look up to know that Shouto’s eyes are locked on the vicious bruises that are already blooming across Izuku’s ribs.

He can feel the weight of his gaze, can feel Shouto’s eyes like a physical touch as they glance over his scared shoulders, at the warped bits of skin on his upper arms, at the small burn brushing across the arc of his left cheek.

Training or not, supervised by the teachers or not, Kacchan hadn’t pulled any of his punches.

And why would he when restraint, especially against Izuku, has never been something high on his list of priorities?

Needless to say the temperature in the locker room had dropped just a bit as soon as Izuku had peeled off his seared and tattered jumpsuit and tossed it down onto the bench.

“I can’t,” Izuku tells him just as quietly because even if Shouto doesn’t know Izuku still remembers Recovery Girl’s warnings.

Bruised ribs and a few burns aren’t enough to risk irritating her over.

Better to save that for something bigger, for something Izuku hasn’t been dealing with his entire life.

“Okay.” Shouto agrees.  He doesn’t ask questions, doesn’t press Izuku for whys or try to convince him, so Izuku doesn’t say anything else on the matter, doesn’t feel that urgent need to explain himself.

Instead Shouto just reaches over and lays a cold hand against Izuku’s bruised ribs, delicate frost spiraling out across his fever hot skin.

The relief is instant but it’s the wordless acceptance that Shouto gives him that means more.

So Izuku lets himself list just a bit to the side, lets himself sway just a bit further into Shouto’s space until his temple is resting against the taller boy’s shoulder.

And Shouto, quiet and solid and there, lets him.

They sit there together in silence for the longest time.

~~~

“You always get hurt,” Shouto says softly just before they go their separate ways for the night.  “Worse than any of us.”

Izuku doesn’t know what to say to that so he just stands there, his back pressed against his dorm room door as Shouto crowds close to his front.

“It’s not so bad,” Izuku knows it’s not, he’s had worse in the past.  The final exam for example had been way worse.  At least this time Izuku knows that nothing is actually broken or dislocated.

“It is,” Shouto presses.  “You just can’t see it like you should.”

There’s a moment of silence.

“I was serious,” Shouto finally says.  “About leaving, about Shiketsu.  About all of it.  I’ll go with you.  We can do this Izuku.  We can be heroes, together, somewhere else.  Somewhere safer for you.”

Izuku’s heart skips a beat.

He’s been doing his best to push that thought, that possible path, down and away since he’d started to really slot himself back into his body again.  Has been trying to make himself believe that it was just a thought brought on by the stale greyness that had consumed him.

It hasn’t been working but Izuku’s kept trying.

“S-Shouto,” Izuku whispers, just a bit lost and reeling like he always is every time he allows himself to really think about leaving UA. 

“How would you feel if it was Iida or Uraraka getting hurt all of the time?  If it was me?” Shouto asks him, something steady and almost understanding in his expression.  “How did you feel when you found out about Endeavour and everything else?  How do you think it feels for me to see you like this, over and over again because no one else seems to see the problem?”

Shouto leans down close enough to press their foreheads together, close enough that they’re breathing each other’s air.

“We’re not heroes yet Izuku,” Shouto tells him just a bit raggedly as he presses even further into Izuku’s space somehow.  “And even with the villain attacks it’s not … it’s not supposed to be like this.  UA was supposed to be different.”

There’s a wealth of unspoken information in that statement, nuance and layers that they’re both aware of but don’t have to actually speak about at the moment.

UA was supposed to be different for both of them in a lot of ways.

And it has been and yet ...

Eyes slipping closed, Izuku basks in that closeness, in the serenity and steady sort of realness that comes hand in hand with being near Shouto.

But all the while his mind click, click, clicks away.

~~~

Later, when Izuku’s in his room with the plastic tote that doubles as his first aid kit open on his bed beside him, he finds himself grinding to a complete halt with Shouto’s words echoing in his head again.

‘What if it was Iida or Uraraka? What if it was me?’

Izuku remembers the fierce and protective rage he’d felt for Iida in that alley.  Remembers his determination to save Uraraka at the entrance exam in part because it was the right thing to do and because she’d been the first person his age to be even passingly nice to him in so long.

Remembers the emotions that had seared him soul deep at the revelation of just what Shouto has had to deal with for so many years from someone who should have kept him safe on more than one level.  The way not even his desire to make All Might proud had been strong enough to keep him from doing whatever he could to help.

Izuku remembers the way he’d thrown himself into the line of fire for each of them, breaking his body into bits and pieces over and over to keep them safe, to help them out of their own personal darkness.

He remembers how much it had hurt him to see them in danger or in pain, just like it always hurts him on some level every time someone in 1-A ends up in a bad position.

Burn cream in one hand and sterile gauze in the other, Izuku goes still as the truth spikes through him, sharp and merciless and sounding just a bit too much like Shouto’s voice in the back of his head.

For a moment Izuku just looks at the medical supplies he’s holding, looks at the tote that he’d spent most of his allowances over the years to get and keep stocked and hidden away from his mom.

Izuku looks and he thinks and he imagines.

For a too long moment Izuku feels as if he can’t breathe through the thick rush of no not them never them not again it’s not right that claws its way to life inside of him.

Izuku’s head fills overfull, his heart feels shredded and the tears that prickle his eyes feel both molten hot and blistering cold.

But in that moment Izuku thinks he finally understands exactly what Shouto’s been trying to tell him.

~~~

With the entirety of his focus bent in one direction, it only takes Izuku a few hours to get everything together for both Shouto and himself.

Transfers between hero schools are unusual but they do happen.  The paperwork, requirements, and forms are out there and easily found even if it’s absolutely unheard of for someone to attempt to transfer out of UA.

UA is, after all, the hero school of Japan.

People who make it into UA tend to stay in UA unless they have absolutely no other choice.

Izuku had once thought he’d be no different.

UA was All Might’s alma mater after all, it was the hero school in Japan, staffed with and attended by the best of the best and it had been Izuku’s dream for as long as he could remember.

But Shouto is right and Izuku is so tired.

He doesn’t want to do this anymore.

Doesn’t want to stay stuck in this same holding pattern of fear and pain and helpless anxiety he’s been trapped in since he was five years old.

Izuku wants to learn, wants to change and grow and finally be free to just be.

And as much as it hurts and aches and burns Izuku doesn’t think he can do any of that here, not really.  He can’t do any of those things to the fullest extent possible with Kacchan looming over him like a guillotine, hovering on the sidelines of his life like a bomb with a hair trigger.

Whatever growth he’d achieve in the long run would be … stunted.

So Izuku doesn’t want to just endure school and training for another two years.  Doesn’t want to study and train and fight during school hours only to have to go back to the dorms afterwards, to the safe place that will never really be safe for him.

He doesn’t want to be forced to live in the same building as someone ready to beat him down with fists and feet and searing explosions at the drop of a hat, at the barest hint of any real or imaginary slight.

Something has to give and, for the first time in his life, Izuku’s not ashamed to admit that, this time, it’s going to be him.

“Hey,” Izuku says softly as he steps up to Shouto’s side, a thick folder tucked neatly beneath his arm and another held out in Shouto’s direction.  “Did some research last night, i-if you’re still serious?”

Shouto takes the folder and flips it open to see what’s inside.

Izuku can tell the moment he realizes just what he’s looking at. 

Transfer papers, scholarship applications, permission slips, and a host of other forms that need to be filled out if they’re really going to do this.

“Absolutely,” Shouto agrees immediately, mouth turned up just a bit at the corners as he closes the folder and reaches out to grab Izuku’s hand in his free one.

“Okay,” Izuku nods, heart pounding but his resolve firm as he twines his battered fingers with Shouto’s.  He is present and aware and real and they are doing this.  “Let’s get started.”

Let Kacchan keep UA just like he’s always wanted.

Izuku’s found something more important.

He’s going to be a hero, side by side with Shouto, no matter what.
